AERO 201#Introduction to Flight and Aerospace Systems#4#ENGR 213; ENGR 233 previously or concurrently#Introduction to flight vehicles in the atmosphere and in space; elements of aerodynamics
column2: airfoils and wings; aerospace technologies including structures
column3: materials and propulsion systems; elements of aircraft performance; basic principles of flight stability
column4: control and systems integration; aspects of aircraft conceptual design. #three hours per week#NA#four hours per week

column1: AERO 371#Modelling and Control Systems#3.5#PHYS 205; ENGR 213
column2: 243; ENGR 311 or ELEC 342 or ELEC 364 previously or concurrently#Definition and classification of dynamic systems and components. Modelling of system components using ordinary differential equations: mechanical
column5: and electrohydraulic subsystems in an airplane. Modelling of systems using transfer function models
column6: block diagrams and signal flow graphs. Linearization of non-linear systems. Transient and steady-state character-istics of dynamic systems. Systems analyses using time domain methods
column8: and frequency response methods. Characteristics and performance of linear feedback control systems. System stability. Proportional
column9: integral and derivative controllers. Simulation technique using Matlab/Simulink. #three hours per week#one hour per week#two hours per week
column10: alternate weeks#Students who have received credit for ELEC 372 or MECH 371 may not take this course for credit.

column1: AERO 390#Aerospace Engineering Design Project#3#AERO 201
column2: 371#General design philosophy and the design process. Design factors such as product safety
column4: life cycle costs and manufacturability. Design in the aerospace context: vehicle and system design with regard to mission require-ments
column10: and validation. Introduction to Computer-Aided Design and Engineering (CAD and CAE). Design documentation. A team-based project in which an aerospace system/subsystem is designed
column12: documented and presented is an intrinsic part of this course. #three hours per week#two hours per week#NA#NA

column1: AERO 417#Standards
column2: Regulations and Certification#3#ENGR 201#Overview of DoT and other international aviation standards (e.g. FAA)
column3: regulations and certification procedures; regulatory areas
column7: aircraft systems design and airworthiness; development process for new regulations and criteria for certification. #three hours per week#NA#NA#Students who have received credit for ENGR 417 or for this topic under an ENGR 498 number may not take this course for credit.

column1: AERO 431#Principles of Aeroelasticity#3#ENGR 243
column2: 311#Aerodynamic loading of elastic airfoils. Phenomenon of divergence. Effect of flexible control surface on divergence of main structure. Divergence of one- and two-dimensional wing models. Phenomenon of flutter. Flutter of two- and three-dimensional wings. Flutter prevention and control. Panel flutter in high speed vehicles
column5: bridge buffeting. #three hours per week#NA#NA#Students who have received credit for MECH 431 may not take this course for credit.

column1: AERO 444#Concurrent Engineering in Aerospace Systems#3#AERO 390#Introduction: objectives
column3: impact on product development; process modelling and optimization; forming of engineering team; selection of techniques
column4: methodology and tools; market design focus vs. quality design focus; development time management; process integration; aerospace case studies/projects

column1: AERO 446#Aerospace Vehicle Performance#3#AERO 464#Introduction to fixed-wing aircraft operation. Flying environment and its measurement by aircraft instrumentation. Computation of lift and drag
column2: effects of viscosity and compressibility. Review of piston
column4: turbojet and turbofan power plants. Operational performance of aircraft in climb
column6: descent and on ground. Advanced aircraft systems. Operational considerations in aircraft design. Projects on selected topics. #three hours per week#one hour per week#NA#NA

column1: AERO 455#Computational Fluid Dynamics for Aerospace Applications#3.75#ENGR 311
column2: 391; MECH 361#Introduction to computational methods in fluid dynamics using commercial CFD codes; aspects of geometry modelling
column5: and post-processing; conversion of CAD to CFD models; an overview of basic numerical methods for the Navier-Stokes equations with emphasis on accuracy evaluation and efficiency. Elements of turbulence closure modelling. User-defined function for customized physical models into commercial CFD codes. #three hours per week#NA#three hours per week

column1: AERO 462#Turbomachinery and Propulsion#3#MECH 351
column3: preliminary sizing and thrust requirements. Rotary and fixed wing aerodynamics and stability. Helicopter configurations. Structure and fatigue design considerations. Review of the gas turbine cycle and components arrangement. Turbo-propulsion: turboprop
column5: turbojet and turboshafts. Energy transfer in turbo­machines: Euler equation
column6: velocity triangles. Dimensional analysis of turbomachines. Flow in turbomachines. Three-dimensional flow in turbomachines. Mechanisms of losses in turbo­machines. Axial-flow turbines and compressors. Centrifugal compressors. Compressor and turbine performance maps; surge and stall. #three hours per week#one hour per week#NA#Students who have received credit for MECH 462 may not take this course for credit.

column1: AERO 464#Aerodynamics#3#MECH 361#Flow conservation equations
column3: inviscid irrotational and rotational flows: the Euler equations
column4: the potential and stream function equations. Dynamics of an incompressible inviscid flow field: the Kelvin
column6: and Helmholtz theorems. Elementary flows and their superposition
column7: panel method for non-lifting bodies. Airfoil and wing characteristics
column8: aerodynamic forces and moments coefficients. Incompressible flows around thin airfoils
column10: vortex sheets. Incompressible flow around thick airfoils
column11: the panel method for lifting bodies. Incompressible flow around wings
column15: swept wings. Compressible subsonic flow: linearized theory
column16: Prandlt-Glauert equation and other compressibility correction rules
column17: the area rule. Transonic flow: Von Karman’s ransonic small disturbance equation
column19: super-critical airfoils. #three hours per week#one hour per week#NA#Students who have received credit for MECH 464 may not take this course for credit.

column1: AERO 465#Gas Turbine Design#3.5#AERO 462#Review of turbo-propulsion types and energy transfer in turbomachines. Two- and three-dimensional flow. Lift and drag for airfoils. Cascade tests and correlations. Aerodynamic losses: physics
column3: control of viscous effects. Preliminary and detailed design of turbines and compressors. Structural and thermal design requirements. Failure considerations: creep
column4: fatigue and corrosion. Performance matching. Combustion and gearbox design. Air and oil systems design requirements. Installations and acoustics. Evolution of design. Recent trends in technologies. #three hours per week#NA#two hours per week
column5: alternate weeks#Students who have received credit for MECH 465 may not take this course for credit.

column1: AERO 480#Flight Control Systems#3.5#AERO 371 or ELEC 372 or MECH 371 or SOEN 385#Basic flight control and flight dynamics principles. Aircraft dynamic equations and performance data. Implementation of aircraft control: control surfaces and their operations
column2: development of thrust and its control; autopilot systems
column4: dynamics and interaction problems. Flight instruments
column5: principles of operation and dynamics. Cockpit layouts — basic configuration
column7: control field forces; advanced concepts in instruments
column8: avionics and displays; HUD; flight management systems
column9: and communication equipment. Introduction to flight simulation: overview of visual
column10: audio and motion simulator systems; advanced concepts in flight simulators. #three hours per week#NA#two hours per week
column11: alternate weeks#Students who have received credit for ELEC 415 or MECH 480 may not take this course for credit.

column1: AERO 481#Materials Engineering for Aerospace#3.5#MECH 221#Different types of materials used in aerospace. Metals
column4: polymers. Failure prediction and prevention. Modes of material failure
column9: impact. Effect of high temperature and multiaxial loadings. High temperature materials. Cumulative damage in fatigue and creep. Materials selection. #three hours per week#NA#two hours per week
column10: alternate weeks#Students who have received credit for MECH 321 or 481 may not take this course for credit.

column1: AERO 482#Avionic Navigation Systems#3#ENGR 371 or COMP 233; AERO 371 or ELEC 372 or MECH 370 or SOEN 385#Basics of modern electronic navigation systems
column3: earth coordinate and mapping systems; basic theory and analysis of modern electronic navigation instrumentation
column7: transmitters and antenna coverage; noise and losses
column10: display systems and technology; demonstration of avionic systems using flight simulator. #three hours per week#one hour per week#NA#Students who have received credit for ELEC 416 or MECH 482 may not take this course for credit.

column1: AERO 483#Integration of Avionics Systems#3#AERO 482#Introduction to the basic principles of integration of avionics systems; review of Earth’s geometry and Newton’s laws; inertial navigation sensors and systems (INS); errors and uncertainty in navigation; Global Positioning System (GPS); differential and carrier tracking GPS applications; terrestrial radio navigation systems; Kalman filtering; integration of navigation systems using Kalman filtering; integration of GPS and INS using Kalman filtering. #three hours per week#NA#NA#Students who have received credit for ENGR 418 may not take this course for credit.
AERO 485#Introduction to Space Systems#3#MECH 351
column2: 361#Classification of space propulsion systems; Tsiolkovskj’s equation; ideal rocket and nozzle design; flight performance; basic orbital mechanics; chemical propellant rocket performance analysis; fundamentals of liquid and solid propellant rocket motors; electric
column4: fusion thruster. #three hours per week#NA#NA#Students who have received credit for MECH 485 or for this topic under a MECH 498 number may not take this course for credit.

column1: AERO 486#Aircraft Stress Analysis#3#ENGR 243
column2: 244#Definition of load paths in typical aircraft structures. Derivation of analysis procedures to enable the designer to size preliminary designs. Internal shear flow distributions that balance external loads. Stress analysis of open and closed cell beams; statically indeterminate beams and frames; single and multi cell torque boxes; symmetric heavy fuselage frames. Structural instability of columns
column4: plates and flanges in compression and shear. Centres of twist and flexure; structural warping; margins of safety; concepts of optimum design; lug analysis and mechanical joints; matrix analysis methods leading to the Finite Element method. Stress analysis of thin-walled metallic structures. #three hours per week#NA#NA#Students who have received credit for MECH 486 may not take this course for credit.

column1: AERO 487#Design of Aircraft Structures#3#AERO 486#Design process for aircraft structures. Aero/performance aspects of aircraft structures. Airworthiness and design considerations. Materials. Static
column2: vibratory and aeroelastic loadings. Propulsion-induced loadings. Functions and fabrication of structural components. Design for buckling of aircraft structures: local buckling
column4: flexural torsional buckling. Design for fracture and fatigue failures. Stress analysis and design of wings
column10: and laminated structures. Design using Finite Element Method. Concept of Optimum Design of Aircraft Structures. Design case studies. #three hours per week#NA#NA#Students who have received credit for MECH 487 may not take this course for credit.

column1: AERO 490#Capstone Aerospace Engineering Design Project#4#75 credits in the program; AERO 390; ENCS 282; ENGR 301#A supervised design
column2: simulation or experimental capstone design project including a preliminary project proposal with complete project plan and a technical report at the end of the fall term; a final report by the group and presentation at the end of the winter term. #one hour per week
column3: one term#NA#NA#Students will work in groups under direct supervision of a faculty member.NOTE: Students who have received credit for COEN 490 or ELEC 490 or MECH 490 may not take this course for credit.
